Era como si su mano hubiera desarrollado una conciencia propia, una conciencia que lo impulsaba a actuar de manera autónoma, sin necesidad de que su cerebro lo ordenara. La mano de Montag se había convertido en un instrumento de rebeldía, un instrumento que lo llevaba a cuestionar la sociedad en la que vivía, una sociedad que prohibía la lectura y la libertad de pensamiento. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.

I often think these days that if I had these kids on my own, without this arrangement, I'd probably be in some kind of trouble. I'd probably be one of those mothers who's accused of neglecting her children. The truth is, I'm not really the maternal type. I do what's necessary, but I don't have the enthusiasm for it that I'm supposed to have. I'm just not wired that way. And I feel guilty about that, of course. I feel guilty because I'm not feeling what I'm supposed to feel. But at the same time, I feel relieved. Relieved that I don't have to do it all by myself. Relieved that I have this arrangement that allows me to have some time to myself, to pursue my own interests, to just be alone sometimes. It's a strange feeling, this mix of guilt and relief. But it's what I've learned to live with.

en_results_raw: and scattered, the books that had been the cause of all the trouble. He felt a pang of regret and loss as he gazed upon the ravaged room, the remnants of a life that had been torn apart by the very things that were meant to bring joy and knowledge. The silence was oppressive, punctuated only by the distant hum of the city and the faint whisper of the wind through the broken windows. Montag's eyes wandered to the spot where the old woman had lain, her body a crumpled heap of flesh and blood, her eyes frozen in a permanent stare. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he recalled the sound of her voice, the words she had spoken, the warnings she had given. And now, she was gone, silenced by the very society she had sought to protect. Montag's thoughts were interrupted by the sound of footsteps, heavy and deliberate, coming from the hallway. He turned to see a group of men, their faces stern and unyielding, their eyes fixed upon him with a mixture of suspicion and hostility. They were the ones who had been searching for him, who had been hunting him down like a wild animal. Montag knew that he had to get out of there, to escape the clutches of those who sought to destroy him. He turned and ran, the sound of his footsteps echoing through the empty halls as he fled into the night, unsure of where he was going, but knowing that he had to keep moving.

en_results_raw: burning sensation was a welcome distraction from the dull ache in his head and the fatigue that threatened to overwhelm him. As he took another sip, he met the gaze of the person who had handed him the cup, a grizzled old soldier with a thick beard and a patch over one eye. The soldier nodded in approval, seeming to accept him as one of their own. The others, a mix of men and women, all dressed in tattered uniforms and armed to the teeth, regarded him with a mixture of curiosity and suspicion. One of them, a young woman with a scar above her eyebrow, stepped forward, eyeing him warily. "Who are you?" she asked, her voice firm but not unkind. He hesitated, unsure how much to reveal, but something about her expression put him at ease. "I'm just a traveler," he said finally, hoping that would be enough. The woman nodded, seeming to accept his answer, and turned to the old soldier. "We should get moving," she said. "We don't have much time." The old soldier nodded, and the group began to stir, gathering their gear and preparing to set out. He watched them, feeling a sense of trepidation mixed with gratitude. He had no idea where they were going, or what they were running from, but for the first time in days, he felt a sense of hope.

Montag se sintió obligado a romper el silencio, a decir algo, cualquier cosa, para aliviar la tensión que se había creado. Pero antes de que pudiera hablar, un sonido lo interrumpió, un sonido que hizo que todos se detuvieran en seco y miraran hacia el horizonte. Era un ruido bajo y constante, como el rugido de un animal gigante que se acercaba. Y entonces, en el horizonte, aparecieron las primeras columnas de humo, que se elevaban hacia el cielo como gigantescos dedos acusadores. La ciudad que habían dejado atrás estaba en llamas, y el infierno había sido desatado sobre la tierra.

The air was heavy with the smell of smoke and sweat, and the sound of distant gunfire echoed through the valley, a constant reminder of the chaos that had erupted around them. As they lay there, they couldn't help but think of their families, their homes, and the lives they had left behind, wondering if they would ever see them again. The earth beneath them seemed to be the only constant, the only thing that remained unchanged in a world that had been turned upside down. And so they held on, their fingers digging deep into the dirt, as if it was the only thing that could keep them anchored to reality.

en_results_raw: small, insistent voice whispered a different answer. It was the voice of his memory, recalling the words of a long-forgotten book, one that he had burned himself, but whose phrases still lingered in his mind like embers. The voice grew louder, urging him to remember the lines, to recall the thrill of discovery that had coursed through him when he first read them. And as he stood there, frozen in indecision, the words began to take shape, forming a question that he could no longer ignore: what was it about those books that was so dangerous, so threatening to the society he lived in? The question sparked a chain reaction of doubts and fears, and Montag felt the ground beneath him begin to shift, as if the very foundations of his world were being undermined.

De repente, una figura emergió de la oscuridad y se acercó a él. Era una mujer, con el cabello despeinado y la ropa desgarrada, pero con una mirada de determinación en sus ojos. —¿Qué estás haciendo aquí? —le preguntó Montag, intentando mantener la calma. —Estoy aquí para proteger mis libros —respondió la mujer, con una voz firme—. Y no permitiré que nadie se los lleve. Montag se sintió sorprendido por la valentía de la mujer y se dio cuenta de que no estaba solo en su lucha contra la censura. Juntos, podrían hacer algo para cambiar el curso de los acontecimientos y preservar el conocimiento que estaba en peligro de desaparecer.

en_first_half: Mildred stood over his bed, curiously. He felt her there, he saw her without opening his eyes, her hair burnt by chemicals to a brittle straw, her eyes with a kind of cataract
en_second_half: unseen but suspect far behind the pupils, the reddened pouting lips, the body as thin as a praying mantis from dieting, and her flesh like white bacon. He could remember her no other way.
en_results: of indifference, her skin pale and almost translucent, like the pages of a book left too long in the sun. The faint scent of perfume wafted from her, a sweet, artificial smell that seemed
en_results_raw: of indifference, her skin pale and almost translucent, like the pages of a book left too long in the sun. The faint scent of perfume wafted from her, a sweet, artificial smell that seemed to cling to her like a shroud. He could sense her gaze upon him, a heavy, oppressive weight that made his skin prickle with unease. And yet, he couldn't bring himself to open his eyes, to confront the reality of her presence, to acknowledge the strange, unsettling feeling that had been growing inside him for weeks. The silence between them was oppressive, a palpable thing that seemed to thicken the air, making it hard to breathe. He felt like he was drowning in it, suffocating under the weight of her unspoken words.

He leaned back in his chair, steepling his fingers together as he continued, "You see, we've been watching you, and we're a bit concerned about your recent behavior." The captain's eyes seemed to bore into Montag's very soul, as if searching for any sign of dissent or rebellion, his voice taking on a slightly patronizing tone, "You're a good fireman, Montag, one of the best, but we can't have you getting too... distracted." The room seemed to grow quieter, the only sound the soft hum of the captain's voice, as he wove a web of words designed to ensnare Montag's thoughts and actions.

A medida que el humo se disipaba, el capitán Beatty comenzó a reflexionar sobre los acontecimientos recientes, y su mente se llenó de pensamientos y recuerdos que habían estado esperando ser procesados. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
en_results: in the lines on people's faces, in the way they walk, the way the light hits their hair. It's not something you can find in the sterile, uniform world we live in today. Không phải anh cần sách đâu, cái anh cần là vài thứ đã từng nằm trong sách. Cũng chính những thứ có thể có trong các 'gia đình phòng khách' hiện nay. en_results_raw: seen it all before, the same old clichés, the same tired metaphors, the same shallow observations about the beauty of nature. And the worst part is, people actually eat it up, they lap it up like the good little sheep they are, never stopping to think for themselves, never questioning the empty platitudes she spouts. I swear, it's enough to make a man lose his faith in humanity.

en_results_raw: and scattered, the books that had been the cause of all the trouble. He felt a pang of regret and loss as he gazed upon the ravaged room, the remnants of a life that had been torn apart by the very things that were meant to bring joy and knowledge. The silence was oppressive, punctuated only by the distant hum of the city and the faint whisper of the wind through the broken windows. Montag's eyes wandered to the spot where the old woman had lain, her body a crumpled heap of flesh and blood, her eyes frozen in a permanent stare. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he recalled the sound of her voice, the words she had spoken, the warnings she had given. And now, she was gone, silenced by the very society she had sought to protect. Montag's thoughts were interrupted by the sound of footsteps, heavy and deliberate, coming from the hallway. He turned to see a group of men, their faces stern and unyielding, their eyes fixed upon him with a mixture of suspicion and hostility. They were the ones who had been searching for him, who had been hunting him down like a wild animal. Montag knew that he had to get out of there, to escape the clutches of those who sought to destroy him. He turned and ran, the sound of his footsteps echoing through the empty halls as he fled into the night, unsure of where he was going, but knowing that he had to keep moving.

The city streets became a maze, a labyrinth with no exit, and he was the rat trapped in its center, searching desperately for a way out. His mind was a jumble of fragmented thoughts and images, a kaleidoscope of fear and anxiety that threatened to consume him whole. The darkness seemed to swallow him whole, and for a moment, he felt a sense of relief wash over him. He had escaped, at least for the time being. But as he stood there, he couldn't shake the feeling that he was being watched, that the eyes of the Mechanical Hound were still trained on him, waiting for him to make another move. He took a deep breath and began to move cautiously through the alley, his senses on high alert, as he tried to put as much distance between himself and the scene of the crime as possible. The streets were empty and silent, the only sound being the soft crunch of gravel beneath his feet. He walked for what felt like hours, his mind racing with thoughts of what he had done, and what lay ahead. He knew he couldn't stay hidden forever, but for now, the darkness was his only refuge.

The sound grew fainter as Montag ran, his footsteps echoing off the houses, until he reached the corner of the street and turned onto the sidewalk. The night air was cool and damp, filled with the scent of wet earth and new life, and Montag felt a sense of freedom that he had not known in years. He ran on, the valise bouncing against his leg, until he reached the outskirts of the city, where the houses grew farther apart and the streets were lined with trees. There, he slowed to a walk, his breath coming in ragged gasps, and looked back at the city, its towers and spires rising like a mirage in the darkness. The rain had stopped, and the sky was clearing, with a few stars twinkling like diamonds in the blackness. Montag felt a sense of wonder at the beauty of the world, and a sense of awe at the mystery that lay before him.

en_first_half: “Listen,” said Granger, taking his arm, and walking with him, holding aside the bushes to let him pass. “When I was a boy my grandfather died, and he was a sculptor. He was also a very kind man who had a lot of love to give the world, and he helped clean up the slum in our town; and he made toys for us and he did a million things in his lifetime; he was always busy with his hands. And when he died, I suddenly realized I wasn't crying for him at all, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood or help
en_second_half: us raise doves and pigeons in the back yard or play the violin the way he did, or tell us jokes the way he did. He was part of us and when he died, all the actions stopped dead and there was no one to do them just the way he did. He was individual. He was an important man. I've never gotten over his death. Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. He did things to the world. The world was bankrupted of ten million fine actions the night he passed on.”
en_results: output>another child in need. I realized then that it wasn't the person that I was going to miss, but the things that he did, the love that he showed, and the memories that he created. And that's what I want you to understand, my friend. It's not the people that we lose that hurt us the most, it's the things that they did, the love that they shared, and the memories that we have of them. That's what makes their passing so difficult to bear.

en_first_half: The men lay gasping like fish laid out on the grass. They held to the earth as children hold to familiar things, no matter how cold or dead, no matter what has happened or will happen, their fingers were clawed into the
en_second_half: dirt, and they were all shouting to keep their eardrums from bursting, to keep their sanity from bursting, mouths open, Montag shouting with them, a protest against the wind that ripped their faces and tore at their lips, making their noses bleed.
en_results: ground as if it was their only lifeline, their only connection to a reality that seemed to be slipping away from them. The air was heavy with the smell of smoke and sweat, and the sound of distant gunfire echoed through the valley, a constant reminder
en_results_raw: ground as if it was their only lifeline, their only connection to a reality that seemed to be slipping away from them. The air was heavy with the smell of smoke and sweat, and the sound of distant gunfire echoed through the valley, a constant reminder of the chaos that had erupted around them. As they lay there, they couldn't help but think of their families, their homes, and the lives they had left behind, wondering if they would ever see them again. The earth beneath them seemed to be the only constant, the only thing that remained unchanged in a world that had been turned upside down. And so they held on, their fingers digging deep into the dirt, as if it was the only thing that could keep them anchored to reality.

es_results_raw: la tierra como si fueran raíces, y sus ojos estaban fijos en el cielo, como si buscaran algo allí, algo que les permitiera entender lo que había sucedido. Algunos de ellos intentaban hablar, pero solo emitían sonidos ininteligibles, como si sus cuerdas vocales hubieran sido dañadas por la falta de oxígeno. Otros simplemente se quedaban allí, inmóviles, como estatuas de piedra, con la mirada perdida en la lejanía. La escena era de una desolación absoluta, como si la propia vida se hubiera escapado de sus cuerpos. Y en medio de todo esto, el silencio era casi palpable, un silencio que parecía tener un peso propio, un peso que aplastaba cualquier intento de movimiento o sonido.

en_first_half: “Now, let's get on upstream,” said Granger. “And hold on to one thought: You're not important. You're not anything. Some day the load we're carrying with us may help someone. But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week
en_second_half: and the next month and the next year. And when they ask us what we're doing, you can say, We're remembering. That's where we'll win out in the long run. And some day we'll remember so much that we'll build the biggest goddam steam-shovel in history and dig the biggest grave of all time and shove war in and cover it up. Come on now, we're going to go build a mirror-factory first and put out nothing but mirrors for the next year and take a long look in them.”
en_results: and we're going to have to go on being very, very careful. We can't let them know what we're doing, or they'll either laugh at us or turn us in. en_results_raw: and we're going to have to go on being very, very careful. We can't let them know what we're doing, or they'll either laugh at us or turn us in. But we have to keep moving, and we have to keep remembering. We have to remember the cities, the libraries, the schools, the universities, the books, the knowledge, the wisdom. We have to remember the past, so that we can build a better future. And we have to do it all in secret, because the ones who rule us now don't want us to remember. They want us to forget, to be ignorant, to be stupid. But we can't let them win. We have to keep the flame of knowledge burning, no matter how small it may seem. We have to keep moving, keep hiding, keep seeking, until the time comes when we can emerge from the shadows and reclaim our rightful place as the guardians of human knowledge and wisdom.
vi_first_half: "Giờ ta đi ngược dòng,” Granger nói. "Và đừng bao giờ buông lơi ý nghĩ này: Các bạn không hề quan trọng. Các bạn chẳng là gì hết. Một ngày nào đó gánh nặng ta mang theo mình có thể giúp cho ai đó. Nhưng ngay cả hồi còn có sách trong tay, đã lâu rồi, chúng ta cũng đâu có dùng những gì thu được từ sách. Chứng ta cứ vậy mà sỉ nhục người đã chết. Chúng ta cứ vậy mà nhổ lên nấm mồ tất cả những người đáng thương chết trước chúng ta. Tuần sau tháng sau năm sau chúng ta sẽ gặp nhiều
vi_second_half: người cô độc. Và khi họ hỏi chúng ta đang làm gì, các bạn có thể nói: Chúng tôi đang ghi nhớ. Ấy là chỗ mà về lâu dài chúng ta sẽ thắng. Và một ngày nào đó chứng ta sẽ nhớ nhiều đến nỗi chúng ta sẽ làm ra cái máy xúc chạy hơi nước to nhất trong lịch sử, đào nấm mồ to nhất mọi thời đại, hất chiến tranh vào đó rồi lấp lại. Nào, trước hết chúng ta sẽ xây một nhà máy gương để trong năm sau sẽ sản xuất ra không gì khác ngoài những tấm gương và nhìn thật lâu vào đó."

es_first_half: —Ahora, vámonos río arriba —dijo George—. Y tengamos presente una cosa: no somos importantes. No somos nada. Algún día, la carga que llevamos con nosotros puede ayudar a alguien. Pero incluso cuando teníamos los libros en la mano, mucho tiempo atrás, no utilizamos lo que sacábamos de ellos. Proseguimos impertérritos insultando a los muertos. Proseguimos escupiendo sobre las tumbas de todos los pobres que habían muerto antes que nosotros. Durante la próxima semana, el próximo mes y el próximo año
es_second_half: vamos a conocer a mucha gente solitaria. Y cuando nos pregunten lo que hacemos, podemos decir: «Estamos recordando.» Ahí es donde venceremos a la larga. Y, algún día, recordaremos tanto, que construiremos la mayor pala mecánica de la Historia, con la que excavaremos la sepultura mayor de todos los tiempos, donde meteremos la guerra y la enterraremos. Vamos, ahora. Ante todo, deberemos construir una fábrica de espejos, y durante el próximo año, sólo fabricaremos espejos y nos miraremos prolongadamente en ellos.
es_results: y el próximo siglo, los hombres seguirán muriendo y muriendo y muriendo, y los libros seguirán siendo quemados. Y aunque no seamos importantes, aunque no seamos nada, nuestra misión es crucial, porque sin ella, la humanidad estaría condenada a repetir los mismos errores una y otra vez. Así que seguiremos caminando, río arriba, llevando con nosotros la carga de la sabiduría y la esperanza de un mañana mejor.
tr_first_half: “Artık akıntının tersine yürüyelim,” dedi Granger. “Bir şeyi kafanızdan çıkarmayın. Sizler önemli değilsiniz. Siz hiçbir şey değilsiniz. Bir gün taşıdığımız yük birine yardımcı olabilir. Fakat uzun süre önce, elimizde kitaplar olduğu zaman bile, onlardan çıkardığımız şeyleri kullanmadık. Ölülere sövmeye devam ettik. Bizden önce ölmüş zavallıların mezarlarına tükürmeye devam ettik. Önümüzdeki hafta, önümüzdeki ay, önümüzdeki yıl, bir sürü yalnız insanla karşılaşacağız. Bize
tr_second_half: ne yaptığımızı sordukları zaman onlara, hatırladığımızı söyleyebilirsiniz. İşte uzun vadede kazançlı olacağımız nokta burası. Bir gün, o kadar çok şey hatırlayacağız ki, tarihin en büyük buharlı kazı makinesini yaparak bütün zamanların en büyük mezarını kazıp, savaşı içine ittikten sonra üstünü örteceğiz.
